## Modelling Approach & Challenges {.smaller}

-   **XGBoost** used for multi-class prediction  
    - Handles non-linear patterns & interactions across survey items

-   Challenge:
    -  Substantial class overlap in PCA space makes preferences hard to distinguish â†’ model fundamentally limited by non-separability
    -  Class imbalance compounds difficulty (e.g. Growth group rarely separable)
    -  Replication on BES 2017 confirms similar structure and class entanglement

## Results & Interpretations {.smaller}

- Model predicts pro-Environment views reasonably well (Sensitivity â‰ˆ 78%)

- Poor performance on Growth and Middle priorities
    - Growth group rarely identified (~5% sensitivity; precision also low at 38%)
    - Middle group inconsistently predicted (~47% sensitivity)

- Strongest predictors include **Green Party affinity, leftâ€“right ideology, ethical consumerism and support for income redistribution**

## Conclusions & Implications {.smaller}


1. **Model performance reveals class imbalance challenges**
   - Accurately predicts Environment group (Sensitivity â‰ˆ 78%)
   - Growth class too small (~8%) for stable learning, even after SMOTE
   - Top predictors (e.g. Green Party affinity, leftâ€“right ideology) support construct validity of H01

2. **Multi-class model retains important nuance**
   - Binary model simplifies attitudes, but collapses moderates into extremes
   - Middle category captures ambivalent or conflicted views â€” key for understanding centrist or swing/undecided voters

3. **Recommendation: Retain H01 in future BES surveys**
   -  Model cannot reliably recover responses for key subgroups â€” especially Growth-oriented respondents
   -  Dropping H01 risks under-representing respondents with economic or moderate priorities, limiting the surveyâ€™s ability to capture the full range of public opinion.
